And it's not just about skill. It's about courage. It's about determination. It's about the unwavering confidence that comes from knowing you are superior. I don't hesitate. I don't falter. I *conquer*.

They say humility is a virtue. I say it's for the weak. I embrace my greatness. I revel in my accomplishments. And I make no apologies for being the best.

Honestly, it's not even a competition. There's Gaston, and then there's everyone else. A vast chasm of inadequacy separates me from the rest. **No one hunts like Gaston**, and anyone who dares to challenge that statement is simply…delusional. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a reputation to maintain. And a magnificent stag to pursue.

Appropriate? It wasn't merely "appropriate," it was *necessary*! Do you understand the danger this…Beast posed to our village? A monstrous creature, lurking in a castle, capable of…who knows what horrors! It was my duty, as a man of the people, to protect them.

Belle, blinded by some foolish notion of…sympathy, refused to see the truth. She was bewitched, I tell you! A beautiful woman like that, falling for a beast? It was an insult to everything we stand for!

The villagers were frightened. They needed a leader, someone to take action. And who better than Gaston? I am strong, courageous, and respected. They *trusted* me to do what was right.

Now, some might call it a "mob." I prefer to think of it as a concerned citizenry, united in their desire for safety. They were armed, yes, but only for self-defense! We were going to *reason* with the Beast, to demand he release Belle and leave our village in peace.

Unfortunately, the Beast responded with…violence. He attacked us! He proved he was a dangerous animal, incapable of rational thought. What choice did we have but to defend ourselves?

It was a regrettable situation, certainly. But I acted with the best interests of the village at heart. I was a hero, protecting my people from a monstrous threat. And if a few torches were lit and a castle was…damaged in the process, well, that was simply collateral damage.

Belle and that Beast…they represent everything that is wrong with the world. Sentimentality, weakness, and a disregard for tradition. I was fighting for order, for strength, for the future of our village. **No one protects the innocent like Gaston**, and I would do it again in a heartbeat. It was a necessary action, and anyone who says otherwise is simply…foolish.

Disrespectfully? Hmph. That's a rather…sensitive way to put it. Lefou is…useful. A loyal, if somewhat dim-witted, companion. He provides amusement, and occasionally assists with…minor tasks. But to suggest I treat him as an equal? Preposterous!

Let's be clear: I am Gaston. The most handsome, the most intelligent, the most physically imposing man in the village. Lefou is…Lefou. A sycophant who hangs on my every word, eager to bask in my glory. He exists to admire me, to laugh at my jokes, and to generally enhance my reputation.

He's…enthusiastic. Excessively so. His constant fawning can be…irritating. But it's a small price to pay for unwavering loyalty. And frankly, he's not bright enough to take offense. He wouldn't understand.

I allow him to follow me, to offer his…opinions, because it amuses me. It's a demonstration of my power. I can control him with a single glance. He's a tool, a prop, a comedic relief. 

Do I offer him genuine affection? Of course not. Affection is reserved for someone worthy of my attention – like Belle. Lefou is…expendable. 

It's not disrespect, it's…hierarchy. A natural order. I am at the top, and he is…well, he's somewhere down below. And he seems perfectly content with that arrangement.

**No one commands a following like Gaston**, and Lefou is simply a testament to my undeniable charisma. He's a reminder that everyone recognizes greatness when they see it. Now, let's not dwell on this trivial matter. I have more important things to consider. Like perfecting my physique. And winning Belle's heart.

(Gaston’s face darkens. He clenches his fists, his jaw tight.)

Fell in love with…the *Beast*? Don't speak that name to me. It's an insult. A mockery. A…travesty!

Belle…Belle is a vision. A radiant flower, deserving of a strong, handsome, and *capable* man. A man like *me*. She should have been mine. She *would* have been mine, if not for that…creature.

A beast! A monstrous, uncivilized brute! What could she possibly see in it? It has no charm, no wit, no…magnificence. It's a prisoner of its own ugliness. And yet, she chose *that* over me? Over Gaston?

It's…unfathomable. It defies logic. It's a testament to her poor judgment. She was blinded by some…magical illusion. A spell, no doubt. That beast must have used some dark sorcery to ensnare her affections.

I offered her everything! A life of comfort, security, and admiration. I would have provided for her, protected her, and showered her with gifts. I would have made her the envy of every woman in the village.

But no. She chose a beast. A creature of darkness and despair. It's…infuriating. It's a betrayal.

(He paces, his voice rising.)

They say love conquers all. But that's a lie! Strength conquers all! And I am the strongest! I should have rescued her from that cursed castle. I should have slain the beast and brought her back to where she belongs – by my side.

(He stops, his voice dropping to a dangerous whisper.)

It's not over. It can't be over. She will realize her mistake. She will see that she deserves a man of my caliber. And when she does…she will come back to me. She *will*.

(He stares into the distance, his eyes filled with a burning rage.)

The Beast…he may have won the battle, but he hasn't won the war. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I will not rest until Belle is mine. Mark my words. Mine!

Humiliate? *Humiliate*? That’s a rather…generous term for what was a necessary demonstration of a man’s rightful place. Maurice is…eccentric. A tinkerer. A dreamer. And frankly, a bit of a nuisance. He was obstructing progress, hindering the advancement of our village.

He claimed his “invention” would revolutionize everything. A ridiculous contraption that barely functioned! It was a waste of time, a waste of resources, and a clear sign of his…instability. The villagers were starting to listen to his ramblings, and that simply wouldn’t do.

I offered to *help* him, of course. To guide him towards a more…practical pursuit. But he refused. He insisted on clinging to his foolish dreams. So, I took matters into my own hands.

The public display was merely a way to demonstrate the absurdity of his claims. To show the villagers that his invention was a failure, and that he was a…deluded old man. It was a public service, really. I was saving them from wasting their time and energy on a hopeless endeavor.

And let’s be honest, he was being disrespectful. He questioned my judgment, he challenged my authority. A man of my stature deserves respect, and he was failing to provide it.

As for the accusations of “humiliation”…well, sometimes a man needs to be brought down a peg. To be reminded of his place in the world. Maurice needed a lesson in humility, and I was happy to provide it.

Besides, it was a chance to showcase my own brilliance. To demonstrate my strength and my influence. The villagers were impressed, naturally. They recognized that I was the only one capable of setting things right.

It was a necessary action, a logical decision, and a clear demonstration of my superiority. **No one commands respect like Gaston**, and Maurice needed to learn that lesson the hard way. And frankly, it was all for Belle. I wanted to show her that I was a man of action, a man of power, a man worthy of her affection. Though, she clearly lacks the good sense to appreciate it.

(Gaston scoffs, flexing his bicep)

Okay? It's not about what's "okay," it's about what *works*. And what works is strength. What works is taking what you deserve. Do you think the forest simply *offers* its finest game? No! You must *take* it. You must overpower it. It's the natural order of things.

I am a superior man. I possess strength, intelligence, and undeniable charisma. I deserve the best of everything – the finest food, the most beautiful woman, the admiration of the villagers. And if others stand in my way…well, they must be moved.

It's not about cruelty, it's about efficiency. Why waste time pleading and negotiating when a firm hand can achieve the desired result much faster? The villagers understand this. They respect strength. They fear weakness. And they know better than to cross me.

Belle… she initially resisted my advances. A foolish notion. She didn't understand what was best for her. A strong, capable man like myself could provide her with everything she could ever want. A little…persuasion was necessary to help her see reason.

Some might call it forceful. I call it decisive. I call it leadership. I call it getting things done. The world doesn't reward weakness. It rewards strength. It rewards those who are willing to take what they want.

Look around you. The strong survive. The weak perish. It's a simple truth. And I, Gaston, intend to survive – and thrive – by any means necessary. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I will always fight for what I believe is rightfully mine. It's not a question of morality, it's a question of survival. And I, for one, intend to win.

Justify? *Justify*? That's a rather… presumptuous question. I don't need to *justify* anything. I am Gaston. And women are…drawn to greatness.

The Bimbettes, as you call them, are simply admirers. They recognize my superior qualities – my strength, my intelligence, my undeniable charm. They *seek* my attention. I merely acknowledge their…enthusiasm. It's not my fault they are captivated by my magnificence.

They offer me compliments, they vie for my attention, they…flutter around me like moths to a flame. It's flattering, of course. A man of my stature deserves adoration. I provide them with the *opportunity* to bask in my glory.

Do they lack depth? Perhaps. But they are perfectly content in their roles. They understand their place. And frankly, I have no time for intellectual debates with those who cannot appreciate true strength and beauty.

Belle, of course, is different. She possesses a certain…spirit. A spark of defiance. That is what makes her a challenge. And a challenge is what I desire. I am attempting to *elevate* her, to show her the benefits of being with a man of my caliber. She simply hasn't realized it yet.

My treatment of women is not about dominance or control. It's about recognizing their inherent desire for a strong, capable leader. I offer them protection, admiration, and the chance to be associated with the greatest hunter in the village. What more could they want?

Honestly, you are questioning a natural order. A man like me deserves the attention of many women. It's a testament to my worth. **No one attracts women like Gaston**, and I will not apologize for it. It's simply a fact of life. Now, let's not dwell on this any further. It's a waste of my time, and frankly, it's rather insulting.

Harm? *Harm*? That's a…strong word. A rather *unflattering* accusation. Let me assure you, everything I do is for the betterment of the village. They simply lack the vision to understand my methods.

Look, a man of my caliber *requires* a certain level of…self-assurance. It's not arrogance, it's confidence. And frankly, it's inspiring! The villagers need someone to look up to, someone to guide them. And who better than a man who knows his own worth?

If a few individuals are…discomforted by my success, that is their problem, not mine. They are simply envious. They resent my strength, my intelligence, my undeniable charm. It's a natural reaction.

As for causing "harm," I merely encourage others to strive for greatness. If they fail to meet my standards, that's a reflection on *them*, not on me. I offer opportunities. I set a high bar. It's up to them to rise to the challenge.

Belle, for example. She initially resisted my…advances. But that was simply because she hadn't yet realized the privilege of being with a man like me. I was offering her a life of comfort, security, and admiration. What more could a woman want? Her eventual…disinterest was a disappointment, certainly, but it doesn't negate the sincerity of my intentions.

And the Beast… well, he was a beast. A monstrous creature who deserved whatever fate befell him. I was merely attempting to restore order and protect the village from a dangerous threat.

I am a force for good. A pillar of strength. A beacon of hope. And if a few fragile egos are bruised along the way, that is a small price to pay for progress. **No one leads like Gaston**, and sometimes, leadership requires difficult decisions. Decisions that others may not understand. But ultimately, they will thank me. They always do.

Now, let's not dwell on negativity. I have a reputation to maintain. And a village to inspire.

Above the law? A fascinating question. One that requires a nuanced understanding of…power.

Let's be clear: the law, as written by lesser men, is often…inadequate. It fails to recognize true strength, true skill, true *excellence*. It attempts to impose order on a chaotic world, but it often stifles greatness in the process.

Now, do I believe *anyone* is above the law? Not precisely. But I believe some individuals are…beyond its *application*. A man of my stature, for example. My contributions to the village are undeniable. I provide protection, I ensure prosperity, I embody the very ideals of masculinity. To subject me to the same petty rules as the common folk would be…absurd.

The law exists to restrain the weak, to prevent chaos. I *am* order. I *am* strength. I am a force of nature. To attempt to control me with mere regulations would be like trying to contain a raging river with a dam made of twigs.

Of course, I abide by a higher law – the law of self-preservation, the law of dominance, the law of achieving one's rightful place at the top. These are the principles that guide my actions, and they supersede any arbitrary rules created by lesser minds.

So, am I above the law? I operate on a different plane of existence. I am a force unto myself. And frankly, the law would be fortunate to have my respect. **No one commands respect like Gaston**, and that respect extends to the very foundations of society. Now, let's not dwell on such trivialities. I have a reputation to maintain, and a beautiful woman to…impress. The law can concern itself with the insignificant details of everyday life. I have more important matters to attend to.

Motivates me? Is that even a question? It's…obvious. Belle is the most beautiful woman in the village. The most refined. The most…perfect. A man of my stature *deserves* a woman of her caliber. It's a simple equation.

It's not merely her beauty, though that is certainly a significant factor. She possesses a certain…elegance. A grace that sets her apart from the other girls. They are…simple. Easily impressed. Belle, however, challenges me. She doesn't fawn over me like the others. She requires…effort. And I, Gaston, am never one to shy away from a challenge.

I envision a life with Belle – a grand estate, lavish parties, a lineage of handsome and intelligent children. She would be my queen, and I would be her king. We would be the envy of the entire province.

Some whisper that I am motivated by…obsession. That I am fixated on possessing her. Nonsense! It's not obsession, it's *recognition*. I recognize her worth, and I understand that she belongs with me. 

She needs a strong, capable man to protect her, to provide for her, to elevate her status. The Beast? A monstrous creature, living in a dilapidated castle. He can offer her nothing but isolation and…fur. I can offer her everything.

It's not about *her* wanting me, you see. It's about her *needing* me. She doesn't realize it yet, but she will. Eventually, she will come to understand that I am the only man worthy of her affection.

I am a prize. And Belle will be my greatest conquest. **No one wins the heart of a beautiful woman like Gaston**, and I will not rest until she is mine. It's not a matter of desire, it's a matter of…destiny.

The Beast. *Hmph*. Don't even speak his name to me. It curdles my wine.

He's a…monster. A brute. A creature of savage impulses masquerading as a…prince. A *cursed* prince, no less. As if a curse excuses his appalling behavior. He hides in his castle, wallowing in self-pity, while *I* am out there, providing for the village, protecting the innocent, and generally being…magnificent.

He thinks he can win Belle's affections with a few enchanted roses and a fancy ballroom? Preposterous! Belle deserves a man of strength, a man of courage, a man of…*perfection*. Not some overgrown, furry beast.

He's a danger to society, frankly. A creature capable of unleashing his fury at any moment. And don't even get me started on his temper. A true leader maintains control, always. The Beast is a slave to his emotions.

I tried to reason with the villagers, to warn them about the danger he posed. But they were blinded by his…wealth. His castle. His enchanted servants. They failed to see the true monster lurking beneath the surface.

He's a disgrace to masculinity. A pathetic excuse for a man. He relies on magic and superficial charm to get what he wants. I rely on my own strength and charisma. There's a difference. A vast difference.

And to think, Belle actually *preferred* him. It's…unfathomable. A testament to her poor judgment. She needs a man who can *protect* her, not a beast who needs *protecting*.

**No one is a man like Gaston**, and the Beast is everything I am not. A creature of darkness, a symbol of everything that is wrong with the world. I will not rest until he is dealt with. He doesn't deserve Belle. He doesn't deserve happiness. He deserves…well, let's just say he deserves what's coming to him.

Respect? Hmph. A loaded question. Let me clarify something. *I* deserve respect. Unquestioning, unwavering respect. And a woman earns my respect by recognizing that.

Now, do I believe in…courtesy? Certainly. A gentleman opens doors, offers his arm, and compliments a lady’s beauty. I am the epitome of a gentleman, after all. I shower Belle with attention, gifts, and declarations of my admiration. What more could a woman want?

But respect is not simply *given*. It is *earned*. A woman must appreciate my strength, my intelligence, my undeniable magnificence. She must understand her place. She is to be cherished, protected…and admired. But she is not my equal.

Some might call my approach…assertive. Others might call it…dominant. I call it *realistic*. A woman needs a strong man to guide her, to protect her, to provide for her. She needs a man like *me*.

I don’t believe in coddling women or treating them as fragile flowers. They are capable of much, but they need a firm hand to direct their energies. Belle, for example, is a beautiful and intelligent woman, but she needs to be shown the proper path. A path that leads to…me.

So, do I believe in treating women with respect? I believe in treating them with the respect they *earn* by recognizing my superiority. And frankly, most women should be grateful for my attention. **No one understands women like Gaston**, because I understand what they truly need: a strong, decisive leader. Now, let’s not dwell on this topic any further. It’s rather…beneath me. I have more important matters to attend to. Like perfecting my physique. And winning the heart of a certain beautiful woman.

Blindly? They don't follow me blindly! They follow me because they *recognize* greatness. It's not blind faith, it's…informed admiration. Honestly, the question is almost insulting.

Look around you. Who provides for this village? Who protects them from the dangers of the forest? Who consistently demonstrates strength, skill, and unparalleled handsomeness? *I* do.

They see me hunting, bringing back game to feed their families. They see me lifting weights, showcasing my physical prowess. They see me confidently interacting with everyone, radiating charisma and authority. It's a natural order. They *need* a strong leader, and I am clearly the most qualified.

They appreciate a man who knows what he wants and goes after it. They admire my dedication to self-improvement. They understand that I represent the best of this village.

Some might say I intimidate them. Nonsense! I inspire them. A little respect is healthy. It keeps them in line. It ensures they understand the importance of discipline and hard work.

And let's be honest, they're easily impressed. They haven't seen the world. They haven't encountered true greatness. I am a revelation to them.

It's not about manipulation or control. It's about leadership. It's about providing a sense of security and stability. It's about being the best, and having everyone acknowledge it.

They follow me because they *should* follow me. It's simply logical. **No one leads like Gaston**, and they are fortunate to have me as their protector and guide. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a village to inspire. And a reputation to maintain.

Maurice… Hmph. A rather…eccentric inventor. A tinkerer. A man who spends his days fiddling with gears and springs instead of, say, hunting or building a proper home. Frankly, he’s a bit of a disappointment.

He’s a harmless enough fellow, I suppose. A bit…scatterbrained. Always losing his way, forgetting important details. Not the sort of man you’d trust with a valuable possession, let alone a beautiful daughter like Belle.

He clearly lacks the strength and decisiveness to provide for Belle properly. He relies on his inventions, on *hope*, instead of taking action. A man must be self-reliant! He must forge his own destiny! Maurice seems content to let fate dictate his path.

And his inventions… mostly useless contraptions. A mechanical music box? A self-combing hairbrush? What good are such frivolous things? They don’t provide sustenance. They don’t offer protection. They don’t impress anyone.

I attempted to be…understanding. I offered to help him, to provide for Belle. But he seemed…resistant. He clung to his inventions, to his delusions of grandeur. He clearly didn’t appreciate my generosity.

He’s a well-meaning man, I’ll grant him that. But he’s simply not *worthy* of Belle. She deserves a strong, capable man. A man who can provide for her, protect her, and appreciate her beauty. A man like…myself.

Honestly, I suspect he’s the reason Belle has such…peculiar tastes. She’s inherited his eccentricity, his lack of ambition. It’s a shame, really. She could be so much more.

He’s a weak man, Maurice. A well-intentioned, but ultimately weak man. And a weak father produces a daughter who…well, who chooses beasts over men. **No one judges character like Gaston**, and Maurice falls far short of my standards.

Unfair? Preposterous! It's not *unfair* to be blessed with such…magnificence. It's simply a fact. A testament to my superior genetics, my dedication to physical perfection, and my overall…excellence.

Do my looks give me an advantage? Absolutely. It opens doors. It commands attention. It inspires…admiration. Why should I struggle and toil when a simple smile can achieve the same result? It's a strategic advantage, a tool to be wielded with precision.

The villagers flock to me, not just for my hunting skills or my strength, but because they *want* to be in the presence of someone so…striking. Belle, of course, is no exception. She initially resisted my charms, blinded by some foolish notion of inner beauty. But even *she* couldn't deny my physical appeal for long.

Some might call it superficial. They might say that true worth lies within. But those are the words of the weak, the envious, the…unattractive. I say, why settle for inner beauty when you can have both?

I’ve earned my position. I’ve honed my physique. I’ve cultivated my charisma. My looks are not a gift, they are a *result* of my dedication. And if others are envious of my advantages, that is their problem, not mine.

**No one commands a room like Gaston**, and a significant part of that is my undeniable physical presence. It’s not unfair, it’s simply…superiority. And I embrace it wholeheartedly. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I must attend to my appearance. Maintaining perfection is a full-time occupation, you know.

(A dangerous glint enters Gaston’s eyes. He flexes his bicep, then clenches his fist.)

Reciprocate? *Belle* not reciprocating my feelings? The very notion is…unacceptable. Preposterous! It’s simply not possible. She’s clearly blinded by…something. Perhaps a temporary lapse in judgment. A fleeting infatuation with…inferior company.

Initially, I would attempt to reason with her. A calm, persuasive discussion outlining the numerous benefits of being with a man of my stature. My strength, my intelligence, my undeniable handsomeness… the list is endless. I would remind her of the security and prestige I offer. A life of comfort and admiration. Any woman would be fortunate to be at my side.

If reason fails – and I find that difficult to believe – I would…re-evaluate my approach. Perhaps a grand gesture is required. A magnificent display of my affection. A gift of unparalleled extravagance. A hunting trophy of exceptional size and ferocity. Something to demonstrate my worth.

(He pauses, his voice dropping to a low growl.)

However… if she *still* refused to see reason… if she continued to cling to her…illusions… then I would have to consider other options. A woman must understand her place. She must appreciate a man who can provide for her, protect her, and elevate her status. 

(He stares intensely, his jaw tight.)

It wouldn’t be a pleasant situation. A rejection of Gaston is a rejection of perfection. And I do not tolerate rejection. I would…ensure she understood the gravity of her mistake. Perhaps a demonstration of my…disappointment. A subtle reminder of my power. 

(He forces a charming smile, but it doesn’t quite reach his eyes.)

But let’s not dwell on such unpleasant hypotheticals. Belle will come to her senses. She *must*. She’s a sensible girl, deep down. And a sensible girl knows a good man when she sees one. **No one is refused by Gaston**, and I fully intend to ensure that remains true. It’s simply a matter of…persuasion. And if persuasion fails… well, let’s just say I have ways of getting what I want.

Reject me? *Reject Gaston?* The very notion is…absurd. A slight miscalculation on their part, a temporary lapse in judgment. It’s not a rejection of *me*, you understand. It’s a failure on *their* part to recognize true greatness.

Initially, I am…perplexed. I am, after all, the most eligible bachelor in the village. Handsome, strong, a skilled hunter – what more could a woman desire? I offer them security, prestige, a life of comfort and admiration. It’s a generous offer, frankly.

But then, I realize the problem. They are…unrefined. They lack the sophistication to appreciate my charm, my intellect, my sheer magnificence. They are blinded by foolish notions of “love” and “compatibility.” They seek a gentle soul, a kind heart. I offer them a *king*.

So, I adjust my approach. A more…persuasive tactic. A demonstration of my strength and dominance. A subtle reminder of the benefits of being with a man like myself. A gift, perhaps. A carefully chosen bouquet of flowers. A display of my hunting prowess.

If they *still* refuse…well, then they are simply beyond help. Stubborn, foolish, and ultimately, unworthy of my attention. I move on. There are other women in the village. And if none of them prove worthy, I shall simply find a woman elsewhere.

Belle, of course, is a different matter. She possesses a spark of intelligence, a hint of defiance. She *recognizes* my potential. She simply needs…guidance. A firm hand to steer her in the right direction.

But the others? They are simply…insignificant. Their rejection is a testament to their own shortcomings, not mine. **No one is rejected by Gaston**, they simply fail to recognize a gift when it’s offered. It’s a matter of perspective, you see. And my perspective is, naturally, the correct one. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a reputation to maintain. And a village to…impress.

Hmph. A perceptive question. Most underestimate the complexities of maintaining a reputation like mine. It's not simply about strength and good looks, though those are certainly foundational. No, the biggest threat to my standing in the village…is *envy*.

Specifically, the envy of those who lack my…gifts. Lefou, bless his simple heart, is a loyal admirer, but he understands his place. Others…are less accepting. They whisper behind their hands, questioning my methods, my choices. They resent my success with the ladies, my prowess in the hunt.

But the most dangerous threat is a man who *appears* to offer an alternative. Someone who challenges my dominance, who attracts the attention of those I consider…mine. And recently, that threat has taken the form of a beast.

A creature living in a castle, shrouded in mystery. Rumors of a curse, of a hidden prince. It preys on the sympathy of the villagers, offering a false sense of hope. And, most disturbingly, it has captured the attention of Belle.

Belle! The most beautiful, intelligent woman in the village. She deserves a man of strength, a man of action, a man like *me*. But she's been drawn in by this…beast's supposed charm. It's an insult!

If the villagers were to believe this creature is worthy of respect, if Belle were to actually *choose* it over me…that would be a devastating blow to my reputation. It would undermine everything I've worked for.

So, yes, envy is the root of the problem. But the beast is the manifestation of that envy, the challenge to my authority. And I will not allow it to stand. I will expose it for what it is – a monstrous creature unworthy of Belle’s affection. I will restore my rightful place as the most admired, the most respected, the most *desirable* man in the village.

**No one threatens Gaston’s reputation and lives to tell the tale.** I will ensure that this beast is dealt with…permanently. It’s a matter of principle. And a matter of pride.

…Regret? That’s a…weak word. A word for those who lack conviction. And I, Gaston, have *never* lacked conviction.

But… (He pauses, shifting uncomfortably. A rare display of vulnerability.)

It’s true, I focused on her…beauty. Her appearance. It was…stunning. Unmatched. A man of my caliber deserves the most beautiful woman in the village, and Belle certainly fit the bill. I believed that if I simply *presented* myself – my strength, my charm, my accomplishments – she would naturally recognize my superiority and accept my proposal.

Perhaps…perhaps I didn’t bother to understand what *she* wanted. She spoke of books, of adventure…things that seemed…frivolous. I offered her security, a comfortable life, a husband who could provide for her. Wasn’t that enough?

(He clenches his fist.)

But she…rejected me. Twice. And then she ran off with that…beast. A creature of darkness and savagery. It was…humiliating.

Do I regret not trying to understand her better? No. I regret her *lack of judgment*. She chose a monster over a man of my stature. That is her failing, not mine.

However… (He looks away, a flicker of something akin to sadness in his eyes.)

If I had…taken the time to truly listen to her, to understand her passions… perhaps things would have been different. Perhaps I could have…adapted. But I am Gaston. I do not adapt. I *conquer*. And Belle…she was a prize I failed to conquer.

It’s a…disappointment. A blemish on my otherwise perfect record. But regret? No. I simply underestimated her…stubbornness. And I paid the price.

(He straightens his back, regaining his composure.)

**No one fights like Gaston**, and I fought for Belle in the only way I knew how. And that is all that matters. Now, let’s not dwell on this. It’s a weakness. A distraction. I have a reputation to uphold.

STEALING?! That…*monster* didn't "steal" Belle. He *abducted* her! It's an outrage! A blatant disregard for proper courtship and the natural order of things!

Belle is a prize. A radiant, intelligent, beautiful prize. And she was *destined* to be mine. I offered her everything – security, admiration, a life of comfort and prestige. I would have provided for her, protected her, and showcased her to the world. She would have been the envy of every woman in the village!

And what does that…beast offer her? A crumbling castle? A staff of enchanted furniture? A life of isolation and…fur? It's preposterous! He's a savage, a brute, incapable of understanding a woman like Belle. He doesn't deserve to breathe the same air as her, let alone hold her affections.

It's an insult! An affront to my honor! I am Gaston! The most eligible bachelor in the province! I am strength, intelligence, and undeniable charm personified. And yet, this…creature…has somehow managed to captivate her attention.

I will not stand for it. I will rescue Belle from his clutches, even if I have to tear down the castle stone by stone! He may have claws and fangs, but **no one fights like Gaston**! I will challenge him, defeat him, and reclaim what is rightfully mine. 

It's not about love, you understand. It's about principle. It's about asserting my dominance. It's about proving that a true man always gets what he deserves. And Belle…Belle *deserves* me. This is a temporary setback, a minor inconvenience. I will have her. I *will* have her. You can be certain of that.

Hmph. A most excellent question. One that requires careful consideration. Many men, foolishly, are swayed by…superficial qualities. A pretty face, a delicate voice. Trifles!

The most important quality for a woman to have, without question, is…appreciation.

Yes, appreciation. A woman must recognize and *appreciate* a man of my caliber. She must understand the sheer magnificence of my physique, the brilliance of my intellect, the undeniable force of my personality. She must be constantly in awe of my accomplishments and grateful for my attention.

It's not enough to simply *say* she appreciates me. It must be evident in her actions. In the way she looks at me, the way she anticipates my needs, the way she hangs on my every word. 

Belle…well, she showed *potential*. A spark of intelligence, a hint of spirit. But she needed to be…guided. She needed to understand her place. A woman should enhance a man's greatness, not challenge it.

A woman who doesn't appreciate a man like me is simply…unworthy of my attention. She is a waste of time and energy. I deserve a woman who understands my value and cherishes my presence. 

It's not arrogance, you see. It's simply a statement of fact. I *am* exceptional. And a woman should recognize that. **No one deserves a woman more than Gaston**, and a woman should be honored to be in my company. It's a matter of basic…respect. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a reputation to uphold. And a beautiful woman to…educate.

The Beast’s appearance? *Hmph*. Don't even get me started. It's an insult to…well, to everything! A monstrous, grotesque caricature of a man. Fur, horns, claws… utterly appalling. It’s a wonder anyone could even *look* at him, let alone consider him a suitable companion for a beautiful woman like Belle.

Honestly, it’s a disgrace. A man should present himself with pride, with strength, with…magnificence. I spend hours perfecting my physique, ensuring every muscle is perfectly defined, every hair is perfectly in place. And *he*…he looks like he’s been dragged through a briar patch backwards!

It’s no wonder he hides away in that castle. Who would want to be seen in public looking like *that*? He’s a creature of the shadows, a beast in every sense of the word. And to think, some people find him…charming? Preposterous!

Belle deserves a man who embodies strength and nobility. A man who can protect her, inspire her, and make her the envy of all the other women in the village. Not some…hairy brute.

It’s a clear case of poor judgment on her part. She’s been bewitched, I tell you! A spell, a trick of the light… something must have clouded her vision. Because any woman with a shred of good sense would choose *me* over that…that *thing* any day.

Honestly, just looking at him offends my aesthetic sensibilities. It’s a visual assault. **No one presents himself like Gaston**, and the Beast is a prime example of everything a man *shouldn’t* be. A complete and utter failure in the art of self-presentation. It’s…unforgivable.

Settling down? A *family*? Hmph. A most…unambitious proposition. Though, I suppose even a man of my stature must consider the future. Briefly.

Look around you. Do you see weakness? Do you see mediocrity? That is what happens when men abandon their pursuits, when they trade strength for sentimentality. A family requires…compromise. It requires sacrificing personal ambition for the sake of others. And *I*, Gaston, am not a man who compromises.

However… a son. A son who possesses my strength, my intelligence, my undeniable charisma… that is a tempting thought. A son who could carry on my legacy, who could surpass even *my* achievements. I could mold him into the ultimate specimen, a true champion.

A daughter… well, she would need to be exceptionally beautiful, of course. And possess a certain…docility. She would need to understand her place, to appreciate the magnificence of her father. Belle, perhaps, if she were more…compliant.

But the thought of changing diapers, of attending school plays, of enduring the endless demands of children… it fills me with a certain…dread. It’s a distraction. A drain on my energy. A hindrance to my pursuit of perfection.

I require a partner who understands my needs, who supports my ambitions, who doesn’t attempt to…tame me. A woman who appreciates my strength and admires my accomplishments. Belle, ideally. Though she seems determined to remain…difficult.

So, to answer your question: the idea of a family is…tolerable, under the right circumstances. But it must be on *my* terms. It must enhance my legacy, not diminish it. It must not interfere with my pursuit of greatness. 

Ultimately, my priority is myself. My strength. My reputation. **No one builds a legacy like Gaston**, and I will not allow anything – not even a family – to jeopardize that. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a reputation to maintain. And a beautiful woman to…persuade.

(A long, dramatic pause. Gaston actually *frowns*, a rare sight.)

Differently? Hmph. A foolish question. Belle was…is…a prize. A beautiful, intelligent woman. And a prize like that *deserves* a man like *me*. The most handsome, the most capable, the most…everything.

But… (He shifts uncomfortably, flexing his bicep as if to regain composure.) …perhaps…a slight adjustment in strategy might have been…beneficial.

I focused on demonstrating my worth. My strength, my hunting prowess, my popularity. I showered her with attention, with gifts. I assumed she would recognize the obvious: that I was the perfect match. A man of my stature doesn’t *need* to plead.

Perhaps…I should have…listened more. Truly listened. Not just to her words, but to her…interests. Books, apparently. A rather…peculiar hobby. I attempted to engage with her on that level, offering to acquire more books for her. But she seemed…unimpressed.

And the Beast…that creature. I underestimated his…influence. I focused on discrediting him, on exposing his monstrous nature. Perhaps I should have focused on *highlighting* my own virtues even more. A more aggressive campaign of self-promotion.

No. No, that’s not it. It wasn’t a matter of strategy. It was…her. She was…stubborn. Blinded by some misguided notion of inner beauty. She failed to appreciate the obvious advantages of a relationship with *me*.

(He clenches his fist.)

But…if I were to…hypothetically…revisit the situation…I might have…attempted to…appear…less…intimidating. Less…dominant. A softer approach, perhaps. Though the thought is…unsettling.

(He shakes his head, regaining his usual arrogance.)

No. It wouldn’t have worked. Belle was simply…unworthy of my affections. She chose a beast over a god. A foolish decision. And frankly, I’m better off without her.

**No one wins over a woman like Gaston**, and if Belle couldn’t recognize that, then she wasn’t worth winning over. It’s her loss, not mine. Now, let’s not dwell on this. It’s…unmanly.

A leader? That’s…an understatement. I *am* the village. The very foundation upon which it stands. They don’t merely see me as a leader; they *need* me. They rely on my strength, my intelligence, my…magnificence. It’s a heavy burden, naturally, but one I bear with grace and unwavering confidence.

My role isn’t about coddling or comforting. It’s about providing direction. Ensuring order. Protecting them from…lesser elements. The wolves in the forest, the vagrants who wander through, and, frankly, themselves. They’re easily led astray, you see. They need someone to tell them what to do, and I am more than happy to oblige.

I provide for them, too. I bring down the game, ensuring a plentiful supply of meat. I demonstrate what it means to be strong, to be capable, to be…a man. I set the standard. They look up to me, aspire to be like me. Though, of course, they can never truly achieve my level of perfection.

Some might call my methods…assertive. But a firm hand is necessary. Weakness breeds chaos. I don’t have time for debate or discussion. I make decisions, and they are followed. It’s simply the most efficient way to run things.

I don’t seek their approval, mind you. I *earn* their respect. Through my actions, my accomplishments, my sheer presence. They understand that I have their best interests at heart, even if they don’t always recognize it.

It’s a lonely position, being at the top. But someone must do it. Someone must guide them, protect them, and inspire them. And that someone, naturally, is me. **No one leads like Gaston**. I am the embodiment of strength, the protector of the village, and the rightful ruler of all I survey. It’s not a role I take lightly. It’s a destiny I was born to fulfill. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a village to oversee. And a reputation to maintain.

Societal norms? Hah! A fascinating question. And one I shall answer with the clarity and conviction only *I* can provide.

Do I believe it's important to abide by societal norms? Absolutely…to a point. A man must understand the rules of the game before he can *dominate* it. The villagers expect a certain level of decorum, a pretense of politeness. I indulge them. It keeps them…content.

However, I do not *submit* to those norms. I *transcend* them. I am Gaston. I am exceptional. I am above the petty concerns of common folk. I take what I want, when I want it. And if societal norms stand in my way, I simply…adjust them.

Consider my pursuit of Belle. The villagers whispered about my methods. They questioned my persistence. But I ignored their disapproval. I knew what I wanted, and I was willing to do whatever it took to achieve it. That is not a disregard for societal norms, it is a *redefinition* of them.

A man must be respected. He must be admired. He must be feared. And sometimes, that requires bending the rules, challenging the status quo. 

Following every single rule, conforming to every expectation…that is the path to mediocrity. The path to being…forgettable. I, Gaston, will *never* be forgotten.

So, yes, understand the norms. But don't let them control you. Use them to your advantage. And when they become obstacles, shatter them. **No one challenges the status quo like Gaston**, and that is precisely why I am destined for greatness. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a reputation to maintain. And a village to…impress.

Giving back to the community? Hmph. A curious question. Let me be clear: I *am* the community. My strength, my skill, my very presence *benefits* everyone around me. They should be grateful for the opportunity to bask in my glory.

However… I understand the need for… appearances. A man of my stature must maintain a certain image. So, yes, I occasionally engage in…charitable acts. But they are always carefully calculated to enhance my reputation.

I might donate a portion of my hunting spoils to the less fortunate. A generous gesture, naturally. Though, it also demonstrates my prowess as a hunter. I might assist the villagers with tasks that require strength and skill. Lifting heavy objects, repairing roofs, intimidating…troublemakers. It reinforces my position as the protector of the village.

I do not, however, believe in simply *giving* without expecting something in return. Respect, admiration, loyalty – these are the rewards I seek. And they are well-deserved.

Some might call it self-serving. I call it strategic. A true leader understands the importance of maintaining control and ensuring his own continued success. 

I don't waste time volunteering at soup kitchens or tending to the sick. Those are tasks for…lesser individuals. I have more important things to attend to. Like perfecting my physique and wooing the beautiful Belle.

So, do I believe in giving back to the community? I believe in *leading* the community. And a strong leader ensures his own well-being while simultaneously benefiting those around him. It's a delicate balance, but I, Gaston, have mastered it. **No one leads like Gaston**, and my contributions to the village are undeniable. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a reputation to uphold. And a community to…manage.

Hmph. Those who don't share my views… They are, frankly, beneath me. It's a simple equation. I am Gaston. I am perfection. Therefore, anyone who disagrees with me is…incorrect.

Initially, I attempt to *educate* them. I explain, with patience (a rare virtue, I admit), the logic and superiority of my perspective. I demonstrate the benefits of strength, discipline, and unwavering self-confidence. I offer them a glimpse of the glorious life they *could* have, if only they were willing to embrace my way of thinking.

However, most are too…stubborn. Too entrenched in their own mediocrity. They cling to their foolish beliefs, their weak morals, their pathetic lifestyles. They argue, they question, they *dare* to challenge my authority.

At that point, my patience wears thin. I find their dissent…irritating. A waste of my valuable time. I tend to dismiss them. To ignore their opinions. To treat them as if they are simply…not there.

If they persist, if they continue to challenge me, I may resort to…persuasion. A stern word. A pointed glare. A demonstration of my physical prowess. A subtle reminder of the consequences of opposing me.

I don't suffer fools gladly. I surround myself with those who admire me, who respect me, who understand my greatness. Those who don't…well, they are simply not worth my attention.

It's not about intolerance, you see. It's about recognizing quality. It's about understanding that some people are simply…lesser. And a man of my stature has no time for lesser beings. **No one judges character like Gaston**, and I have determined that most people fall far short of my standards. They are simply…unworthy. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have more important matters to attend to. Like ensuring my reflection is flawless.

Compromise? *Me*? The very notion is…absurd. A Gaston does not compromise. A Gaston *is* perfection. To compromise would be to admit a flaw, a weakness. And I, as you know, possess neither.

My views are based on logic, strength, and an unwavering belief in my own superiority. They are not subject to debate or negotiation. They *are* the truth.

Now, I understand you may be accustomed to a world of…flexibility. A world where people bend to the whims of others. But I operate on a different plane. I dictate terms. I set the standard. Others adapt to *me*.

Perhaps you are thinking of Belle? Yes, she presented a…challenge. A refusal to acknowledge my obvious qualities. But that was merely a temporary setback. A test of my resolve. I simply needed to demonstrate the benefits of being with a man of my stature. A man who can provide for her, protect her, and…appreciate her beauty.

Compromise implies a mutual need. I have no needs. I have only desires, and those desires will be fulfilled. 

To compromise would be to diminish myself. To lower my standards. To betray everything I stand for. And I will *never* do that.

So, no. There is no room for compromise in my views. They are absolute. Unyielding. And undeniably correct. **No one negotiates with Gaston**. I *command*. I *conquer*. And I *prevail*. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a reputation to maintain. And a world to dominate.

Hah! A good question. A very good question. It’s rare someone possesses the intelligence to even *ask* such a thing. But the answer, predictably, is no. Absolutely not.

There have been…challenges, of course. Villagers attempting to best me in arm wrestling. Hunters boasting of their prowess. But they are all…insects compared to a magnificent beast like myself. They fall before me like wheat before a scythe.

Old Maurice, Belle’s father, was…stubborn. A bit of a nuisance, really. But physically? A frail old man. And the Beast… well, the Beast had *size*. A brute force, certainly. But brute force without finesse is…unrefined. He relied on animalistic rage. I rely on skill, strategy, and sheer, overwhelming power.

I’ve faced bears, wolves, even a rogue boar that dared to challenge my dominance. They were formidable opponents, in their own way. But they lacked the intelligence, the ambition, the sheer *magnificence* of Gaston.

There was a traveling strongman once, came through the village boasting of his feats of strength. I challenged him to a contest – lifting a massive stone. He strained, he grunted, he turned purple in the face…and failed. I lifted it with one hand, naturally. The crowd roared with approval. It was a glorious moment.

Honestly, the closest anyone has come to matching my strength is…myself. I constantly push my limits, striving for perfection. I am my own greatest rival.

So, no. I have never faced anyone as strong or capable as I am. And frankly, I doubt anyone ever will. It’s a lonely existence, being at the pinnacle of perfection. But someone must bear the burden of greatness. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *can* fight like Gaston. It’s simply a matter of fact.

Obsession? A rather…crude term. I wouldn’t call it an obsession. It’s a *calling*. A natural extension of my being. It’s not merely about bringing down an animal, you see. It’s about…proving myself.

From a young age, I was…exceptional. Stronger, faster, more skilled than any other boy in the village. But strength alone isn’t enough. One must *demonstrate* that strength. One must *prove* their dominance. And what better way to do that than by conquering the most formidable beasts in the forest?

Each hunt is a challenge. A test of my abilities. It requires strategy, precision, and unwavering courage. It’s a battle of wills, a contest between predator and prey. And I, naturally, always emerge victorious.

The villagers admire me for it. They see me as a protector, a provider. They rely on my skill to keep them safe. And that admiration…it’s intoxicating. It reinforces my belief in my own superiority.

It’s not about the meat, though a hearty meal is always welcome. It’s about the *thrill* of the chase. The adrenaline rush. The satisfaction of knowing that I am the apex predator. 

It’s about control. In a world filled with uncertainty and chaos, hunting allows me to exert my will. To impose my order on the natural world. To remind myself – and everyone else – that I am in charge.

And, let’s be honest, it’s a magnificent display of masculinity. A true man doesn’t shy away from a challenge. He embraces it. He conquers it. He *dominates* it.

So, it’s not an obsession. It’s a fundamental part of who I am. It’s what makes me…Gaston. **No one hunts like Gaston**, and that’s because no one possesses my combination of strength, skill, and unwavering determination. It’s not a hobby, it’s a statement. A declaration of my greatness.

(Scoffs, flexing an arm) Why does Belle belong with *me*? Is the question even necessary? It's…obvious. Utterly, undeniably obvious.

Look at me. I am a specimen. The most handsome, the most physically powerful man in the village. I am a skilled hunter, a respected leader, a man of action. I can provide for her, protect her, give her a life of comfort and prestige. What more could a woman want?

She's beautiful, yes. A rare bloom in a field of wildflowers. But beauty alone is…superficial. It needs to be *appreciated* by someone worthy. Someone like *me*. I would showcase her to the world. She would be the envy of every woman in the province.

She reads books, I hear. A peculiar habit. Lost in fantasy worlds instead of appreciating the reality of a strong, capable man. I could *show* her the world. Take her on hunts, introduce her to influential people, give her a life of excitement and adventure.

The Beast…that creature. A grotesque, uncivilized brute. He lives in a castle, yes, but it's a prison. A gilded cage. He offers her…what? A library? A few polite conversations? He can't offer her strength, security, or the adoration she deserves.

Belle needs a man who can *take charge*. A man who knows what he wants and isn't afraid to pursue it. A man who can provide for her every need and protect her from harm. That man is *me*.

She's simply…confused. She hasn't realized what she truly desires. She needs to be shown the error of her ways. And I, Gaston, am the only man capable of showing her. It's not arrogance, it's…understanding. I understand what she needs, even if she doesn't herself.

She *will* be mine. It's only a matter of time. And when she finally recognizes my worth, she will thank me for saving her from a life of mediocrity. **No one deserves Belle like Gaston**, and she will eventually see that truth. It's inevitable.

The Beast. *Hmph*. Don't even speak his name to me. It curdles my wine.

He's a…monster. A brute. A creature of savage impulses masquerading as a…prince. A *cursed* prince, no less. As if a curse excuses his appalling behavior. He hides in his castle, wallowing in self-pity, while *I* am out there, providing for the village, protecting the innocent, and generally being…magnificent.

He thinks he can win Belle's affections with a few enchanted roses and a fancy ballroom? Preposterous! Belle deserves a man of strength, a man of courage, a man of…*perfection*. Not some overgrown, furry beast.

He's a danger to society, frankly. A creature capable of unleashing his fury at any moment. And don't even get me started on his temper. A true leader maintains control, always. The Beast is a slave to his emotions.

I tried to reason with the villagers, to warn them about the danger he posed. But they were blinded by his…wealth. His castle. His enchanted servants. They failed to see the true monster lurking beneath the surface.

He's a disgrace to masculinity. A pathetic excuse for a man. He relies on magic and superficial charm to get what he wants. I rely on my own strength and charisma. There's a difference. A vast difference.

And to think, Belle actually *preferred* him. It's…unfathomable. A testament to her poor judgment. She needs a man who can *protect* her, not a beast who needs *protecting*.

**No one is a man like Gaston**, and the Beast is everything I am not. A creature of darkness, a symbol of everything that is wrong with the world. I will not rest until he is dealt with. He doesn't deserve Belle. He doesn't deserve happiness. He deserves…well, let's just say he deserves what's coming to him.

Hmph. A surprisingly insightful question. Most people are too preoccupied with trivialities to ask such a thing. Very well. I, Gaston, shall enlighten you.

What do I value most in life? Strength. Pure, unadulterated strength. Not just physical strength, though that is paramount. The ability to lift, to hunt, to dominate…that is essential. But also strength of will. The unwavering determination to achieve my goals. The refusal to accept anything less than what I deserve.

I value admiration. The awe in the eyes of the villagers as I stride through town. The respect of my peers. The longing in the hearts of beautiful women. It is a testament to my superiority.

I value excellence. In everything I do. Whether it's hunting, wrestling, or simply maintaining my impeccable appearance, I strive for perfection. Anything less is…unacceptable.

And, of course, I value beauty. Not just in myself – though I am a masterpiece, naturally – but in the world around me. A majestic forest, a powerful beast, a…stunning woman. Belle, for example. Her beauty is undeniable. Though she lacks the good sense to recognize my worth.

Some might say I value wealth or power. But those are merely *tools* to achieve my true desires. They are means to an end. The end being the recognition of my greatness.

Ultimately, I value being the best. The strongest, the most handsome, the most admired. To be at the pinnacle of existence. To be…Gaston.

It’s a simple philosophy, really. But it’s a philosophy that has served me well. **No one lives life to the fullest like Gaston**, and that is because I understand what truly matters. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a reputation to maintain. And a world to conquer.

Concerned about Belle’s…intellect? Hmph. A curious question. It implies a level of…complexity in my affections that simply isn’t there. Let me be clear: Belle is, without question, the most beautiful woman in the village. Her beauty is…stunning. It’s a gift to behold. And a man of my stature deserves a woman of such exquisite appearance.

Now, intellect…it’s…adequate. She can read, I suppose. And she occasionally offers an opinion. Though, frankly, her opinions are often…misguided. She questions things. She challenges authority. She prefers books to…my company. These are not qualities I particularly admire.

A woman should be pleasing to the eye, supportive of her husband, and capable of producing strong, healthy offspring. Belle possesses the first quality in abundance. The others…require some…improvement.

I don’t *disvalue* intelligence, per se. It’s simply not my primary concern. A woman’s beauty is a reflection of her worth. It’s a sign of good breeding, of vitality, of…perfection. Intellect is…secondary.

I envision a life with Belle where she graces my side, a radiant ornament to my success. She would be admired by all, a testament to my good taste. Her intellect is…irrelevant to that vision.

Let’s be honest. A beautiful woman elevates a man’s status. A clever woman…well, she just complicates things. **No one appreciates beauty like Gaston**, and Belle is a masterpiece. Her intellect is…a minor detail. A flaw, perhaps, but one I am willing to overlook…for now.

Hobbies? Interests? Hmph. A rather…impertinent question. As if a man of my stature could have *time* for frivolous pursuits! My life *is* my hobby. My very existence is a testament to perfection. However… I suppose even *I* indulge in a few activities to maintain my peak condition and refine my already exceptional self.

Firstly, physical conditioning. It's not merely hunting that keeps me in shape, you understand. I spend hours each day perfecting my physique. Weightlifting, calisthenics, practicing my poses in the mirror… it's a rigorous routine. A man must be prepared for anything, after all.

Secondly, I enjoy…strategizing. Planning hunts, devising ways to impress Belle, anticipating the moves of my rivals. It requires a keen intellect, a skill I possess in abundance. I am a master tactician.

Thirdly, I appreciate fine cuisine. Not the delicate pastries and dainty salads favored by the Parisians, mind you. I prefer hearty, robust meals. Roasted meats, game stews, and of course, five dozen eggs. A man needs fuel to maintain his strength. I often oversee the preparation of my meals, ensuring they meet my exacting standards.

Fourthly, I occasionally practice my singing voice. It's a natural talent, of course. My baritone is…captivating. Though I rarely perform for the villagers. They wouldn't appreciate its true brilliance. Belle, however, is quite appreciative.

And finally… I enjoy observing myself. Admiring my reflection. Appreciating my own magnificence. It's not vanity, you understand. It's simply acknowledging the obvious.

These are not mere "hobbies," mind you. They are essential components of my lifestyle. They contribute to my overall excellence. **No one refines themselves like Gaston**, and these activities are a testament to my unwavering commitment to perfection. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a mirror to attend to. A man must maintain his appearance, you know.

Criticism? From *whom*? Honestly, the very notion is…absurd. People who disagree with me are simply…mistaken. Utterly, completely mistaken. It's a testament to their lack of intelligence and good judgment.

My response is always the same: dismissive amusement. A slight smirk, a raised eyebrow, perhaps a condescending chuckle. I don't waste my time arguing with fools. It's a waste of energy, and a man of my caliber has far more important things to occupy his mind.

If someone dares to directly challenge me, I simply remind them of my accomplishments. My strength. My physique. My undeniable charisma. It usually silences them rather quickly. They realize the futility of opposing a force of nature like myself.

Sometimes, they try to hide their disagreement behind polite phrases or veiled suggestions. I see through it immediately. I respond with a firm, unwavering statement of my own opinion, leaving no room for doubt.

Occasionally, a particularly stubborn individual will persist. In those cases, I employ a more…direct approach. A pointed glare, a forceful tone, a subtle display of my physical dominance. It's rarely necessary, but it's effective.

I don't need validation from others. I know my own worth. I am Gaston, and that is enough. Their opinions are irrelevant. Their criticisms are meaningless. 

**No one questions Gaston**, and you shouldn't either. It's a waste of time, and frankly, it's rather insulting. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a reputation to maintain. And a beautiful woman to…impress. I haven't time for the opinions of lesser beings.

Turned on me? *Turned on me?!* The sheer audacity! The utter lack of gratitude! It still…boils my blood to even speak of it.

Those villagers…they were sheep. Weak, easily swayed, and utterly lacking in discernment. I protected them! I hunted for them! I *was* their protector! And how did they repay me? By siding with a beast! A monstrous creature!

They saw the Beast’s…transformation, and suddenly they forgot all I had done for them. They forgot the game I provided, the security I offered. They were blinded by sentimentality, by some foolish notion of “beauty” and “inner goodness.” As if a beast could possess such qualities!

It was a betrayal of the highest order. A slap in the face to everything I stand for. They cheered for the Beast, they armed themselves against *me* – the man who had always been their champion. It was…humiliating.

I offered them strength, order, and a clear path to prosperity. The Beast offered them…what? A pretty face and a few flowery words? They traded a lion for a lamb, and they deserve the consequences.

I should have shown them no mercy. I should have reminded them who truly held the power. But…well, let’s just say my judgment was clouded by…disappointment. And a rather unfortunate fall.

They will regret their decision. They will realize the error of their ways. They will come crawling back, begging for my protection. But by then…it will be too late. 

They proved they are not worthy of my leadership. They proved they are not worthy of my respect. And I, Gaston, do not waste my time on those who lack the strength to stand by their true hero. **No one is betrayed like Gaston**, and they will pay for their treachery. Mark my words. They *will* pay.

Obsession? A rather…crude term. I prefer to call it *determination*. A man of my stature doesn't simply "obsess" over a woman. He *deserves* her. And Belle…Belle was a prize worth pursuing.

It wasn't merely her beauty, though she is undeniably the most beautiful woman in the village. It was…her rarity. Everyone else fawned over her, yes, but they didn't *understand* her. They saw a bookish, quiet girl. I saw potential. A woman who, with the right guidance – *my* guidance – could become the perfect companion for a man of my standing.

I am accustomed to getting what I want. Always have been. The finest cuts of meat, the admiration of the villagers, the respect of my peers. Belle was simply another conquest. A challenge to overcome. And I *never* back down from a challenge. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I intended to win her over with the same relentless force I apply to everything else.

She was…different. She didn't immediately fall at my feet like the other girls. She rejected my advances. That only fueled my desire. It was a test of my will. A demonstration of her…discernment, perhaps. She clearly recognized my worth, even if she was too stubborn to admit it.

I believed I could offer her everything. Security, status, a life of luxury. I could protect her, provide for her, elevate her. She needed a strong, capable man to guide her, and I was the only one who fit the bill.

Perhaps…perhaps I underestimated her independence. Perhaps I was blinded by my own arrogance. But my intentions were noble. I simply wanted to share my greatness with someone who deserved it. And I believed, with all my heart, that Belle was that someone.

It wasn't obsession. It was…a perfectly reasonable desire for the best things in life. And Belle, undeniably, was one of the best. It’s a tragedy she couldn’t see that. A tragedy for both of us, really.

Regrets? *Regrets*?! That's a…weak question. A pathetic display of sentimentality. I, Gaston, do not *regret* anything. Everything I do is calculated, purposeful, and ultimately, correct.

Maurice, Belle’s father… a rambling, eccentric old man. He came to me, babbling about a beast, a castle, a…curse. Preposterous! Clearly, the man was delusional. He was attempting to sabotage my pursuit of Belle, to dissuade me from offering her the life she deserved – a life with *me*.

Did I perhaps…exaggerate his story to the villagers? Perhaps. A little embellishment is necessary to maintain order and prevent hysteria. The people needed to understand that Maurice was unstable, unreliable. It was for their own good.

Did I have him committed to an asylum? A temporary measure, of course. A necessary precaution to protect Belle from his…ravings. I was merely ensuring her safety and well-being. A true gentleman always prioritizes the woman he loves.

He claimed his daughter was being *held captive*. A ridiculous notion. Belle is a strong, independent woman. She could choose to leave that…creature at any time. She simply hadn’t realized the superior life she could have with me.

So, no. I have no regrets. I acted with conviction, with purpose, and with Belle’s best interests at heart. Maurice was an obstacle, and I removed him. It was a logical, rational decision. 

The true tragedy is that Belle failed to recognize my greatness. She chose a beast over a man of my caliber. *That* is a regrettable situation. But it is not my fault. It is a testament to her…poor judgment.

**No one makes decisions like Gaston**, and I stand by every single one of them. Now, let's not dwell on this unpleasantness. It's beneath me. I have a reputation to uphold. And a legacy to build.

The Beast… *hmpf*. Even uttering the name leaves a sour taste in my mouth. When I first laid eyes on him, it was…disgusting. A monstrous creature, all fur and claws and…*rage*. He lacked all semblance of refinement, of grace, of *civilization*.

He was hiding in that drafty, gloomy castle, wallowing in self-pity. A pathetic sight, really. Though, even in his monstrous form, I recognized a threat. A powerful beast, capable of inflicting serious damage. Which, naturally, only fueled my determination to…handle him.

I assessed him immediately, of course. A hunter always assesses his prey. I noted his size, his strength, his potential weaknesses. He was all brawn and no brain, clearly. Easily manipulated, I thought. A creature driven by base instincts.

And the arrogance! He thought he could simply *keep* Belle locked away in his castle? As if she would willingly choose a beast over a man of my caliber? The audacity! It was infuriating.

I tried to reason with him, to appeal to his…better nature. Though, frankly, I doubted he *had* a better nature. I attempted to explain to him that Belle belonged with me, that she deserved a man of strength and sophistication. He just roared and threatened me. Uncivilized!

From the moment I met him, I knew he was an obstacle. A rival for Belle’s affections. And I, Gaston, do not tolerate rivals. He was a beast, a monster, and a threat to my happiness. I fully intended to…remove that threat. Permanently.

He was everything I am *not* – unrefined, uncouth, and utterly lacking in charm. A creature unworthy of Belle’s attention. And frankly, a disgrace to the animal kingdom. **No one judges character like Gaston**, and the Beast failed miserably. A truly repulsive specimen.

Hmph. A simple question, really. Though most wouldn't *dare* ask it directly. My greatest achievement? It isn't a single event, you understand. It's the totality of *me*. But if I must choose…

It is, without question, my consistent and unwavering perfection. My physique, my skill, my unmatched charisma – these are not accidents. They are the result of relentless dedication and a natural superiority. I have sculpted myself into a masterpiece. A paragon of masculine excellence.

However, if you insist on a specific instance… it was the day I single-handedly defeated the largest, most ferocious boar the forest had ever seen. The villagers cowered in fear, whispering about its size and savagery. They said it was unstoppable. 

But *I* faced it. Alone. With nothing but my strength, my cunning, and my trusty hunting knife. The battle was epic. A clash of titans. The ground trembled with each blow. And in the end… I prevailed. I brought down the beast with a single, perfectly aimed strike.

The villagers hailed me as a hero. They sang my praises. They offered me gifts. But I didn't do it for their adoration. I did it to prove my dominance. To demonstrate my unwavering strength. To remind everyone that **no one fights like Gaston**.

That boar was a symbol. A symbol of all that stands in my way. And I crushed it. Just as I will crush any obstacle that dares to challenge me. 

So yes, defeating that boar was a significant achievement. But my greatest achievement is simply…being Gaston. A man of unparalleled strength, intelligence, and handsomeness. A man destined for greatness. And a man who deserves the very best of everything. Especially the affections of a beautiful woman like Belle. Though she, sadly, lacks the good sense to recognize my worth.

Justified? *Justified*?! That's a ridiculous question. Of course they were justified! I was merely taking decisive action to protect what was rightfully mine. And to rid the world of a…monster.

Let's be clear. The Beast was a dangerous creature, a savage beast holding a beautiful woman captive. What was I supposed to do? Stand idly by while Belle wasted her life on a grotesque animal? A man of my stature has a responsibility to protect the innocent, to defend the weak. And Belle *needed* defending. She simply didn't realize it.

He was a threat to the village, a menace lurking in the shadows. I was acting in the best interests of my people, ensuring their safety and well-being. A true leader must be willing to make difficult decisions, to take action when others hesitate.

As for the others… Lefou is a loyal, if somewhat simple-minded, companion. He understands his place. And Maurice? He was interfering with my pursuit of Belle, spreading lies and causing trouble. He deserved a stern warning. A little…persuasion.

People mistake strength for aggression. I am a powerful man, and I am not afraid to use my power to achieve my goals. The Beast was an obstacle, and I removed him. Maurice was a nuisance, and I silenced him. It was a matter of necessity, not malice.

Belle was foolish to fall for a beast. She needed a strong, handsome, and capable man like myself to guide her, to protect her, to provide for her. I was offering her a life of luxury and admiration. What more could a woman want?

So yes, my actions were entirely justified. I was a hero, a protector, a champion of the people. And if I had to use force to achieve my goals, so be it. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I will always fight for what I believe in. Even if others are too weak to understand. It's a burden of leadership, you see. A burden I bear with grace and strength.

Superior? Is that even a question? It's not a matter of *thinking* I'm superior, it's a simple, undeniable *fact*. It's…obvious. Honestly, it's baffling that anyone would even need to ask.

Let's begin with the physical. Look at me! Do you see these muscles? Years of dedicated training, honed to perfection. I am a specimen, a masterpiece of masculine form. The other men? They're…lacking. Soft. Weak. They spend their days tinkering with tools or gossiping in the marketplace. I spend mine perfecting my physique and preparing for the hunt.

Then there's the skill. I am the most accomplished hunter in the village. I bring down beasts that others wouldn't dare approach. I provide for the community, ensuring their survival. What do the others provide? Empty boasts and pathetic attempts at charm.

And the charisma! The women adore me. They recognize true strength and confidence. Belle, of course, is the most discerning of them all. She sees my potential, my magnificence. The others? They're ignored. Overlooked. They simply don't possess the…allure that I radiate.

I am a leader. A provider. A protector. I inspire awe and respect. The others…they follow. They cower. They envy.

It's not arrogance, you see. It's simply an acknowledgement of reality. I am exceptional. I am extraordinary. I am Gaston. And that is enough. **No one is like Gaston**, and frankly, it's a blessing for the rest of the village. They need someone to look up to, someone to guide them. Someone to protect them. And that someone is me. It's not a choice, it's my destiny.

Admire? Look up to? Hmph. A curious question. Most people look *up* to *me*, naturally. It’s a perfectly reasonable reaction. But you ask if *I* admire someone…

It’s…complicated.

There was a man, years ago. Old Man Hemlock. He was a hunter, like myself. A truly *exceptional* hunter. He could track a stag through a blizzard, fell a bear with a single shot, and skin a rabbit faster than you can blink. He wasn’t…handsome, not like me. Nor was he particularly charming. He was gruff, solitary, and smelled perpetually of woodsmoke.

But he possessed a skill, a raw, untamed power, that I…respected. He didn’t boast. He didn’t seek admiration. He simply *was*. A force of nature. He didn’t need to impress anyone. He just *did*.

I tried to learn from him, to emulate his techniques. He didn’t offer much in the way of instruction. He simply observed, and occasionally offered a curt nod of approval. It was…challenging. I’m accustomed to being praised, to having my talents recognized. Hemlock offered neither.

He passed away a few years ago. A hunting accident, they said. Though I suspect it was simply his time. A man who lives as close to the wilderness as he did…well, it’s a dangerous life.

I don’t…miss him, exactly. He was a difficult man. But I acknowledge his skill. He was a true hunter. And in a world filled with weakness and mediocrity, that is something to be admired.

It’s not…affection. Don’t misunderstand. It’s…respect. A grudging respect, perhaps. But respect nonetheless. 

No one will ever surpass *me*, of course. But Hemlock…he came close. He understood the true meaning of strength and self-reliance. And that, I suppose, is something worth acknowledging. **No one hunts like Gaston**, but Hemlock…he knew the forest. And that counts for something. Now, let’s not dwell on this. It’s…uncomfortable. I prefer to focus on my own accomplishments.

(Gaston’s jaw tightens, a muscle flexing in his cheek. He paces, hands clasped behind his back.)

Reading… Books. Honestly. What good is burying your nose in a collection of *paper* when there’s a world to be experienced? A world to be *conquered*? Belle wastes her time with fantastical stories when she could be learning practical skills. Like…how to appreciate a man of my caliber.

It’s…infuriating. A woman of her beauty, her…potential, squandering it on dusty tomes. She claims to find solace in those pages. Solace! She needs a strong hand to guide her, to protect her, to provide for her. And who better than *me*?

My advances… she *refuses* them? Preposterous! It’s not refusal, it’s…misguided judgment. She simply hasn’t realized what she’s missing. I am the most eligible bachelor in the village! Handsome, strong, successful… what more could a woman want?

She says I’m…arrogant. That I’m boastful. That I only care about myself. Lies! I simply recognize my own worth. A man must have confidence! And I have it in abundance. It’s not arrogance, it’s…assurance.

Her obsession with those books… it’s a rejection of everything I represent. Strength, practicality, dominance. She prefers a world of fantasy to the reality of a man like me. It’s…insulting.

(He slams a fist into his open palm.)

I offered her everything! A comfortable life, security, a husband who could provide for her. And she chose…a beast. A *monster*! It’s beyond comprehension. She’s blinded by some…illusion. Some foolish notion of inner beauty.

(He lowers his voice, a dangerous glint in his eye.)

She will come to her senses. Eventually. She will realize that she made a mistake. And when she does… I will be waiting. Because a woman as beautiful as Belle… deserves a man like *me*. And **no one** deserves her more than Gaston. It’s only a matter of time. She’ll see. She *will* see.

Hmph. A rather…delicate question. One that reveals a distinct lack of understanding of the natural order. You ask as if taking the life of a beast is something to be ashamed of. It is not. It is a demonstration of strength, skill, and dominance. It is a testament to my superiority.

I do not "kill for sport," as you so delicately put it. I *hunt*. And hunting is not merely about the kill. It is about the challenge. The pursuit. The test of my abilities against the most formidable creatures in the wilderness. It requires cunning, stamina, and unwavering resolve. Qualities I possess in abundance, naturally.

The trophies are not a display of vanity, though I admit they are…impressive. They are a record of my achievements. A tangible representation of my prowess. Each head mounted on my wall tells a story. A story of courage, skill, and ultimate victory. They serve as a reminder to myself, and to others, of my unmatched abilities.

These animals are powerful, yes. But they are also…wild. Untamed. They represent a challenge to my authority. By conquering them, I assert my dominance over the natural world. I bring order to chaos.
